video.title: Python NumPy Tutorial for Beginners
video.description:
Learn the basics of the NumPy library in this tutorial for beginners. It provides background information on how NumPy works and how it compares to Python's Built-in lists. This video goes through how to write code with NumPy. It starts with the basics of creating arrays and then gets into more advanced stuff. The video covers creating arrays, indexing, math, statistics, reshaping, and more.

💻 Code: https://github.com/KeithGalli/NumPy

🎥 Tutorial from Keith Galli. Check out his YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCq6XkhO5SZ66N04IcPbqNcw

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (01:15) What is NumPy
⌨️ (01:35) NumPy vs Lists (speed, functionality)
⌨️ (09:17) Applications of NumPy
⌨️ (11:08) The Basics (creating arrays, shape, size, data type)
⌨️ (16:08) Accessing/Changing Specific Elements, Rows, Columns, etc (slicing)
⌨️ (23:14) Initializing Different Arrays (1s, 0s, full, random, etc...)
⌨️ (31:34) Problem #1 (How do you initialize this array?)
⌨️ (33:42) Be careful when copying variables!
⌨️ (35:45) Basic Mathematics (arithmetic, trigonometry, etc.)
⌨️ (38:20) Linear Algebra
⌨️ (42:19) Statistics
⌨️ (43:57) Reorganizing Arrays (reshape, vstack, hstack)
⌨️ (47:29) Load data in from a file
⌨️ (50:20) Advanced Indexing and Boolean Masking
⌨️ (55:59) Problem #2 (How do you index these values?)

⭐️ Links with more info ⭐️
🔗 NumPy vs Lists: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC_mmB9WkzXQAQmwj6EPmXQw
🔗 Indexing: https://docs.scipy.org/doc/numpy-1.13.0/user/basics.indexing.html
🔗 Array Creation Routines: https://docs.scipy.org/doc/numpy/reference/routines.array-creation.html
🔗 Math Routines Docs: https://docs.scipy.org/doc/numpy/reference/routines.math.html
🔗 Linear Algebra Docs: https://docs.scipy.org/doc/numpy/reference/routines.linalg.html

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://www.freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.author: WahranRai
topLevelComment.text:
17:37 Indexing is not coherent in Python :
we start from index 0 and with negative indexing from -1 (why not -0?! or starting from 1 as in R (Rstudio)

replies.author: Dog Explores World
replies.text: the -1 doesn't have anything to do with indexing. It's the number of elements you step back from the end. The - means step back, the 1 is number of steps you take.

replies.author: LercDsgn
replies.text: @WahranRai why not?

replies.author: WahranRai
replies.text: @LercDsgn No !

replies.author: LercDsgn
replies.text: probably because indexing is made with integers and in integers, -0 evaluates to 0 anyway

topLevelComment.text:
while assigning a 2 dimension or more in np.array if we the dimension of any of the list exceed it is treated as a separate list 
like eg: a=np.array([[1.0,2,3.5,3],[1,2,3,4]]) they both have the same numbers of elements 4 and 4 
but if:c=np.array([[1.0,2,3.5,3],[1,2,3,4,5]]) now they have different values 4 and 5 and using the print command is is treated as a separate list. 
is this considered to be a syntax error or we can use it in some ways

topLevelComment.author: Corey Hillesheim
topLevelComment.text:
56:02
# Easy way to make the array
np.reshape(np.arange(1,31),(5,6))

replies.author: Corey Hillesheim
replies.text:
Simplified form
np.arange(1,31).reshape(6,5)
or this...
np.arange(30).reshape(6,5)+1

replies.author: Corey Hillesheim
replies.text:
This works, too.
np.reshape(np.linspace(1, 30, 30, dtype='int'),(5,6))

topLevelComment.author: Corey Hillesheim
topLevelComment.text:
31:50
def init_array(rows, columns):
    p = np.zeros((rows, columns), dtype='int8')
    p[0,:] = p[-1,:] = p[:,0] = p[:,-1] = 1
    p[p.shape[0]//2, p.shape[1]//2] = 9
    return(p)
init_array(5,5)

arr = np.ones((5,5))
arr[1:len(arr) - 1,1:len(arr) -1) = 0
row_mid = int(len(arr - 1)/2)
col_mid = int(len(arr[0] - 1)/2)
ones[row_mid,  col_mid] = 9

It work for all row = 2n+1 col = 2n + 1

topLevelComment.author: Codotaku
topLevelComment.text:
Numpy is fast because the heavy duty is done in C, while python only gives commands on what to do with the data.
Also small contiguous memory helps with cache locality, faster operation and CPU vectorized processing without mentioning the utterly small footprint.
A good rule of thumb, if you find yourself making large loops and lists, you should consider numpy right away.

topLevelComment.text:
Answer for 31:34

import numpy as np

a=np.ones((5,5),dtype='int8')
b=np.zeros((3,3),dtype='int8')
a[1:-1,1:-1]=b
a[2,2]=9
print(a)

replies.author: anurag parcha
replies.text:
You don't need to create b. It just wastes memory. Just do this:
i5 = np.ones((5,5))
i5[1:4,1:4] = 0
i5[2,2] = 9
print(i5)

topLevelComment.author: Surendra Satyanarayan
topLevelComment.text:
*Problem ONE:*
_Create an N x M 2-D numpy array. Take N and M input from the user. Then write a Python code to find the sum, mean, maximum, minimum, argmax and argmin of the array on each axis individually._

*Problem TWO:*
_Create an N x M 2-D array. Take N and M input from the user. Also, take the whole array input from the user. Now take another special input P. Write a Python code which tests whether P is greater than any of the elements in rows (axis 1) or in columns (axis 0). Output the individual rows and columns indices where such a condition is true._

*PROBLEM THREE:*
_Find the sum of the diagonal elements of a user-input N x N matrix. Broadcast this scalar quantity onto an array of shape (20,) and get the product of the broadcasted scalar and the array._

*PROBLEM FOUR:*
_Take i and j input from the user which helps her access and output (i,j)th element k of a 2-D array. Finally multiply the 2-D array with k and output the result._

*PROBLEM FIVE:*
_Create a M-D NxN numpy (matrix) array. Extract the M diagonals and represent them in a matrix where each row corresponds to each M._

*PROBLEM SIX:*
This is an example of *structured array* (already done in class).

_import numpy as np_
_student =_ _np.dtype([('name','S20'), ('age', 'i1'), ('marks', 'f4')])_
_a = np.array([('abc', 21, 50),('xyz', 18, 75)], dtype = student)_
_print(a)_

_Write a full fledged Python program where the user can input the name, age, class, address, marks and grade of each student. The program should be able to print individual "series" as well. For example, if the user wants check all the names, the program should be able to output the same._
Can u solve this..

topLevelComment.author: lou Naguez
topLevelComment.text:
this was my solution
one=np.ones(5)
x=np.asmatrix(one)
matrix=np.repeat(x,5,axis=0)
matrix[1:-1,1:-1]=0
matrix[2,2]=9

topLevelComment.author: achintha isuru
topLevelComment.text:
For the part in 35:10,

It is happening because Lists / Arrays are 
mutable by nature. This means once you created them you cannot change it.
Do a google search about this, you will find more details.

topLevelComment.author: Gokul
topLevelComment.text:
⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (01:15) What is NumPy
⌨️ (01:35) NumPy vs Lists (speed, functionality)
⌨️ (09:17) Applications of NumPy
⌨️ (11:08) The Basics (creating arrays, shape, size, data type)
⌨️ (16:08) Accessing/Changing Specific Elements, Rows, Columns, etc (slicing)
⌨️ (23:14) Initializing Different Arrays (1s, 0s, full, random, etc...)
⌨️ (31:34) Problem #1 (How do you initialize this array?)
⌨️ (33:42) Be careful when copying variables!
⌨️ (35:45) Basic Mathematics (arithmetic, trigonometry, etc.)
⌨️ (38:20) Linear Algebra
⌨️ (42:19) Statistics
⌨️ (43:57) Reorganizing Arrays (reshape, vstack, hstack)
⌨️ (47:29) Load data in from a file
⌨️ (50:20) Advanced Indexing and Boolean Masking
⌨️ (55:59) Problem #2 (How do you index these values?)
